Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the effectiveness of chemotherapy by stating that it doesn't work 97% of the time. This is an overstatement of the actual success rate of chemotherapy.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that doctors only recommend chemotherapy to receive kickbacks. This is a problematic assumption that lacks evidence and generalizes the motives of all doctors.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient support and evidence to back up the statement that chemotherapy doesn't work 97% of the time. It relies on the testimony of one doctor and misrepresentation of a study.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts established medical facts about the effectiveness of chemotherapy in treating cancer. It goes against the consensus of the medical community.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to consider alternative explanations for why doctors recommend chemotherapy, such as medical evidence, clinical trials, and patient-specific factors.
Understate: The claim understates the potential benefits and successes of chemotherapy by focusing solely on negative outcomes and disregarding cases where chemotherapy has been effective in treating cancer.
